Description: Small cast models of situla and situla-stand in copper alloy; bag-shaped situla with pronounced button-shaped, pointed base; two opposite vertical suspension rings welded at mouth (both broken), handle missing; separate hollow cuboid stand with six open sides; both undecorated and heavily corroded.
Curator's comments: Situlae were used for libation of water or milk (Junker 1913, 10). This specimen, however, is just a model and not an actual piece of temple equipment. Situlae in metal, decorated or not, are common votive objects of the Late and Ptolemaic Period. They were massively produced ex-votos that visiting pilgrims dedicated in temples and shrines (see the chapter on situlae in Green 1987, 66-115). At least seven specimens were collected from Naukratis early excavations. Green, C. I. 1987, The Temple furniture from the Sacred Animal Necropolis at North Saqqâra 1964-1976 (Egypt Exploration Society Memoirs 53), London, 66-115. Junker, H. 1913, Das Gotterdekret über das Abaton, Vienna.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (MC.02) (phase 3)
